title-group.article-title: Dynamic torsion of laminar beams as a working principle for sensors

contrib-group.aff: CNISM, Department of Physics, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, Modena, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Bruno Morten, CNISM, Department of Physics, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, via G. Campi, 213/A, 41100, Modena, Italy. Email: bruno.morten@unimore.it

abstract.p: A method is presented in order to put planar structures in a pure torsion, by directly acting from their surfaces where a stress state is induced, taking advantage of piezoelectric layers that are integral with them. An experimental investigation was carried out on alumina beams which, in a portion of their faces, support two ferroelectric layers of lead zirconate titanate created using conventional thick-film technology processes. A suitable system of coplanar electrodes, embedded in the layers, promotes piezoelectric deformations parallel to the substrate, induced by a voltage across them. At the layer–substrate interfaces, completely in-plane stresses are created, and when they are conveniently oriented, the beam is prompted into pure torsion, which takes on the characteristics of a vibration following the application of alternated voltage. Besides describing the design and realization of the sample beams, this study reports on their dynamic behaviour in torsion, the experimental set-ups and the procedures for its characterization. The results are discussed and highlighted in order to outline the potential of the method with regard to using the realized beams as primary sensors for physical quantities. To this end, proposals for possible devices are considered, and an application of beams in a force sensor is also reported.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The research work of the authors follows a cultural design, whose aim is to find applicative proposals for the physical phenomena studied, within the scope of the sensors and actuators area. The characterizing activities aim, on one hand, to investigate such phenomena in specific materials and, on the other, to devise suitable structures that are potentially usable for the development of new families of devices. With this in mind, an experimental study was undertaken to evaluate the feasibility of laminar beams that ‘self-generate’ a condition of pure torsional vibration and their applicative potential for possible sensors. Special laminar structures in specific dynamic conditions are the subject of this investigation, in order to highlight new applicative aspects of torsion as a sensing phenomenon.

Torsion of fibres, wires, discs and beams constitutes an effective and reliable technique that is widely implemented in the operation of numerous sensors. There are in fact several devices whose sensing function is carried out by elastic elements, which, operating in static or dynamic conditions, detect the input of physical stimulus. By way of example, few applications are here cited: use of induced torsion in fibers for studies of anisotropy in ferromagnetic single crystals (Penoyer, 1959) and flux-lattice in superconductors crystals (Farrell et al., 1991). Use of torsional vibrating wires as ultrasonic waveguides in sensors for density and viscosity measurements (Shepard et al., 1999) and flow front monitoring of fluids (Visvanathan and Balasubramaniam, 2007). Use of a torsion bar coupled with metallic beam resonators in a torque sensor (Whitehead et al., 1997) and guided torsional waves in a stiff metal rod for the sensing of liquid levels (Spratt et al. 2009).

Studies on the torsional vibrating modes of elastic plates have highlighted high values of quality factor and properties that are of practical interest in the design of resonators and sensors (Knowles et al., 2005). Likewise, from the theoretical analysis of the resonance of rectangular cantilevers immersed in fluids, the results were obtained whose extension to the torsion modes provided interesting solutions for environmental sensing (Van Eysden and Sader, 2006). Sensing elements consisting of beams in torsion are implemented in several designs of microfabricated sensors as, for example, resonating and integrated cantilevers in devices for the detection of bio/chemical molecules (Jin et al., 2007; Li et al, 2009).

In order to create torsional vibration, the elastic elements involve coupling to transducers that are necessary for providing the dynamic twisting forces through actuation mechanisms that are generally based on piezoelectric (Davis et al., 2010; Spratt et al., 2009; Visvanathan and Balasubramaniam, 2007; Whitehead, et al., 1997), electromagnetic (Jin et al., 2007; Li et al., 2009) or piezomagnetic (Shepard et al., 1999) effects. Due to the care required by the coupling of the functions of sensing and vibration generation, the variety of constructional solutions adopted must satisfy special limiting conditions in order to give the optimal sensor performance characteristics.

This study reports on an innovative and simple method resulting from the combination of knowledge of the properties of deformable media, design of transducers for the piezoelectric generation (detection) of deformations and the realization procedures. Its implementation allows dynamic conditions of pure torsion to be created without any restraint due to the aforesaid coupling. Laminar devices consisting of alumina beams that support ferroelectric layers were especially devised and realized by using the standard materials and processes of thick-film technology (TFT). The experimental set-ups, which were especially designed, are described together with the measurement procedures. The results are shown and discussed with the aim of outlining the potential of the method with regard to exploiting the vibrating devices as primary sensors of physical quantities. To this aim, considerations regarding the development of new and possible dynamic sensors for specific areas of use are also reported. As an example, a sensor proposal for the measurement of axial forces is also included.

sec.title: Surface stresses and beam torsion
sec.p: It is well known that according to linear theory, the stress state of a cylindrical bar in conditions of pure torsion involves only shear components on the sections carried out with planes perpendicular and parallel to its axis. Figure 1 shows their distribution, as well as stresses of the same amount at the points of external surface where they take on their maximum value.

caption.p: Stress distribution in a cylindrical bar in torsion: (a) on sections obtained with planes parallel to its axis and (b) on a cross section.

sec.p: For a prismatic bar with a rectangular and constant cross section, the condition of pure torsion entails that within the limits of small deformations, the shear stresses on the external surface do not have a constant amount but change their value from zero at the corners up to a maximum at the median points (Bucciarelli, 2008; Timoshenko, 1970). This is represented in Figure 2 for a bar where the width is much larger than the thickness as in the case of a laminar cantilever beam, whose free end is subjected to a couple of forces with the moment along its axis. Ultimately, the external surface of a beam in a condition of pure torsion is where only the stress components parallel to the surface are present.

caption.p: (a) Deformed state of a laminar cantilever beam under the action of a couple of forces with the moment parallel to the axis and (b) stress distribution on the cross section (τmax and τmax′ are the maximum values of shear stress at the median position along the width and thickness directions, respectively).

sec.p: In order to set in torsion the beam by acting from its surface, rather than through the application of couples at its ends, conditions need to be created that exactly induce only shear components of the stress on it. However, this is not sufficient to obtain an effect of pure torsion as can be seen in Figure 4, which shows deformation schemes for a cantilever beam in three different orientations of the surface shear stresses (Fenner, 1989; Gere and Timoshenko, 1991).

caption.p: Deformed configurations of the beam and its cross section after the application of shear stresses from the surface with different orientations with respect to its longitudinal axis: (a) parallel, (b) along transverse direction and (c) at 45°.

sec.p: For a surface shear stress oriented parallel to the axis, the longitudinal profile of the beam is that of a bending; its cross section maintains the rectangular form but has a lowering (Figure 4(a)). The stress state of the beam consists of a pure bending. For shear stresses oriented perpendicular to the axis, the transverse profile is that of an arc of a circle; the whole cross section takes the non-rotated form shown in Figure 4(b) with the concavity directed up or down depending on the sign of the stresses. Figure 4(c) indicates the configuration for an intermediate orientation of the shear stresses, which can be read as the concurrent effect of bending and torsion due to the combination of Figure 3(a) and (b). The cross section is subjected to an angular displacement compared to that of the fixed end.

It must be emphasized that a torsion component only exists for the intermediate orientations and that, in spite of its rotation, the cross section has a different form with regard to that at the fixed end besides being non-parallel to it. The application of a pure shear stress on the opposite surface of the beam sets a similar condition of deformation. If the strength and direction of the stresses on both surfaces are identical, the bending components are opposite, whereas the torsion ones are concordant.

Therefore, it follows that the bending effect disappears and the torsion one only remains by virtue of the cross section rotating around the longitudinal axis by maintaining its rectangular form. So, the beam is in a condition of pure torsion whose extent depends on angle ϕ between the stress orientation and the longitudinal axis (Park et al., 1996). Accordingly, along the stress direction, a strain εϕ is induced, which must be analysed in order to find the value of the angle ϕ of which the angular displacement of the cross section at the beam’s free end, and then the torsion moment, is the maximum. For the same amount of surface stress, the corresponding strain εϕ always exhibits, within the limits of Hooke law’s, the same value, whatever angle ϕ is. Nevertheless, the components of the surface stress along the longitudinal and transverse directions induce strains for the same directions that are different for any value of angle ϕ. In this case, the relationship holds

where εx and εy are the strains corresponding to the effects shown in Figure 4(a) and (b). In the extreme cases of ϕ = 0° and ϕ = 90°, no torsion exists, while for the intermediate ones, where both components of the strain coexist, the beam is in pure torsion. It follows that within this angular range the torsion moment will be at a maximum for an angle ϕ by which the two contributions on the right side of equation (4), having a constant sum, simultaneously take the same value. It occurs when the orientation of the surface stress is at 45° with respect to the longitudinal axis.

It can therefore be concluded that through the generation of a stress at 45° to the axis on both surfaces and in a symmetrical position, it is possible to induce a laminar beam in a condition of pure torsion with the highest value of the related moment.

sec.title: Prototype sample and torsion induced by surface stresses
sec.p: A method has been devised that allows torsion to be created in a ceramic laminar beam by acting on its surfaces, where equal stresses totally in plane are simultaneously created in symmetrical portions of it. Its implementation takes advantage of the piezoelectric deformation of pre-polarized ferroelectric layers realized on those surface portions by means of the standard procedures and materials of TFT. Materials in the form of paste, consisting of a dispersion of inorganic powders in an organic carrier, are transferred by screen-printing onto a substrate that is a part of the same beam surface where a deposit with a predetermined form and dimension is left.

The layers are made up of fine ceramic grains of lead zirconate titanate (PZT) strengthened in a macrostructure after a specific high-temperature firing treatment and are formed following one multiple screen-printing and firing step, which is required to obtain a predetermined overall thickness. They are provided with an appropriate system of coplanar and interdigitated electrodes obtained from a metallic paste, based on a gold powder, screen-printed and fired on or inside the same layers that act as a substrate. Thanks to its high level of flexibility, the TFT does not put restraints on the placement and disposal of the electrodes with regard to the layer and beam. Figure 5(a) shows the layout of the electrode system designed for this work, and Figure 5(b) shows its position inside the thick-film layer.

caption.p: Sample prototype: (a) electrode pattern; (b) exploded representation of the thick-film layer with the electrode system; (c) appearance of the instrumented sample in cantilever version; (d) photograph: 1 – interdigitated electrode system as realized on an alumina beam surface, 2 – complete real sample where one of the two piezoelectric layers is visible.

sec.p: In order to take advantage of the spontaneous polarization of each microscopic ferroelectric grain, the layers were submitted to a poling process carried out at a temperature of 150°C for 60 min in the presence of an electric field (2.5·106 V/m), by means of a direct current (DC) voltage across the electrodes. The layers were then returned to room temperature, the voltage was removed, and their remaining macroscopic polarization P, parallel to the beam surface, took place. Its direction is the same along which piezoelectric deformations, which may be static or dynamic, depending on the application of a constant or alternated voltage to the electrodes, are generated in the layers. This is a necessary condition to obtain stress totally in plane on the beam surface, below the layers, generated by the opposing action of the beam against the creation of those deformations. An external electric field present in the medium among the electrode fingers induces in it a strain ε, which, within the limits of linear theory, is given by the relationship: ε=dE with d effective piezoelectric constant of the layer material. It accounts for the strain amount when the electric field E and polarization P are parallel to each other and play the role of d33 coefficient in the parent bulk PZT piezoceramic (Jaffe et al., 1971). The electrode pattern was designed and oriented, so that below the thick-film layers, on both the beam surfaces, only shear stress is generated at 45° to the axis; this gives the maximum amount to the pure torsion of the beam.

Figure 5(c) shows the set-up of a prototype sample consisting of an alumina beam (96% Al2O3) instrumented with the piezoelectric layers and used in the cantilever version for investigating its dynamic behaviour in the torsion conditions.

A few samples were made with a rectangular and constant cross section, which were 400 µm thick and had a width of 13 mm. In Figure 5(d-2), a particular of a real sample is shown. Each piezoelectric layer had rectangular geometry and an overall thickness of about 100 µm. As a cantilever beam, its length from the mechanical constraint of one end is 114.7 mm and each thick-film layer fills up 18.15 mm of it.

sec.title: Experimental set-ups and characterization methods
sec.p: A survey was carried out to characterize the sample oscillations, evaluate their connection with pure torsion and accurately define the frequencies of the vibration modes. To this aim, suitable equipment was especially designed and assembled according to two investigation methods based on a microphonic technique and a circuit allowing measurements of electrical impedance (admittance) depending on frequency, respectively. The experimental set-ups for their implementation are described later.

sec.title: Microphonic method
sec.p: Figure 6(a) shows the functional pattern of the experimental set-up used for the amplitude measurements of the vibration in a surface portion of the beam. This was carried out by a capacitive microphonic sensor {4} placed in proximity to the surface and at a known distance from it. It converts the acoustic pressure at its input into an electrical signal, whose amplitude is proportional to the displacement of the beam portion with regard to its equilibrium position. A sweep frequency generator {3}, directly connected to the electrodes of the layers, excites the beam vibration. The sensor output, through a conditioning {5} and amplification {6} chain, produces a signal whose form is displayed on an oscilloscope {8}, while its root mean square (rms) value is indicated by a true rms voltage meter {7}. A mechanical system of translation allows the sensor to move along both the longitudinal and transverse directions of the beam with displacements of micrometrical resolution.

caption.p: (a) Experimental set-up for the amplitude measurement of vibrations: {1} – supporting structure; {2} – prototype sample fixed at one end to the structure; {3} – sweep frequency generator (HP-33120A); {4} – capacitive microphonic sensor (Bruel & Kjaer-4138); {5} – signal conditioner; {6} – amplifier; {7} – rms voltage meter HP 3403C; {8} – oscilloscope Tektronics 465. (b) Sensor position with respect to a beam cross section in the absence and presence of torsion.

sec.title: Admittance spectrum
sec.p: Figure 7(a) gives a schematic representation of the experimental set-up for the accurate measurement of the frequency of the sample vibration modes, by recording an admittance spectrum. For the sweep frequency generator {3} the sample represents the electrical load of a piezoelectric transducer of impedance Z. The amount of the latter is equivalent to that of the circuit shown in Figure 7(b) when the frequency is close to resonance (Ikeda, 1990). C0 is the capacitance of a layer, C and L are the reactive components of circuit indicating the elastic and inertial properties of the piezoelectric film, respectively, while R is related to the dissipative phenomena occurring in it. Figure 7(b) also shows the frequency response of the equivalent circuit in terms of its admittance Y (= 1/Z). It highlights a linear trend according to the relationship |YC0|=wC0, except for the presence of some anomalies in behaviour. Each of them is characterized by a maximum and minimum admittance that occur by two frequencies namely, resonance and anti-resonance, respectively. In this work, the construction of a curve representing the frequency dependence of |Y| allows the values of those frequencies that identify the vibration modes of a prototype sample to be found. With a voltage from the sweep frequency generator {3} of constant amplitude VG, |Y| is proportional to the current I in the piezoelectric layer; therefore, a spectrum can be obtained from the measurement of such a current depending on the frequency. This is made possible by adding a functional block {4} consisting of a differential circuit, coupled in current (Figure 7(c)), to the measuring chain that plays a fundamental role in identifying the vibration modes. The current I in the sample goes through the primary coil L1 of a transformer at the secondary of which, L2, a voltage V2 is induced that is directly proportional to I, with an experimentally measured transformation constant KI. The same current also flows both in the primary coil L1′ of a second transformer and in the capacitor C0′ equal to C0, which, not having a ferroelectric dielectric, exhibits an admittance proportional to the frequency without anomalies. The induced voltage V2′ at the secondary coil, L2′, also proportional to current I, is present in the input of the differential amplifier {5} together with V2. At its output, a voltage signal is provided, which is registered by a plotting system {7}, and when expressed in terms of the admittance difference |Y|−|YC0|, it takes on the form of Figure 7(d) where the peaks correspond to the frequencies of the sample vibration modes. The output voltage signal from the measuring chain, VY, is proportional, at those frequencies, to the amplitude of the admittance peak, Y, according to the relationship

sec.title: Measurement procedures and results
sec.p: The displacement values of a sample portion in conditions of vibration were obtained by moving a microphonic sensor placed in proximity to the surface at a constant distance from it. The measurements performed with the set-up of Figure 6(a) followed an experimental program of three steps.

The first concerned the sensor being positioned near a surface portion close to the beam’s free end where the maximum angular displacement is expected (Figure 2(a)). The amplitude of the latter, converted into a voltage signal at the output of the measuring chain, is a function of the excitation frequency that, in this case, was manually modified within a range of 0–10 kHz. The voltage, by reaching its maximum values for certain excitation frequencies, allowed the natural vibration modes of the prototype sample to be detected. Their measured frequencies, together with the rms values of the voltage signal and torsion angle, and the mode indication are shown in Table 1. Also shown are the frequencies predicted by equation (2), where the values of beam density ρ and shear modulus G were separately measured.

caption.p: Measurement results with the sensor placed next to the sample’s free end on a surface portion where the maximum angular displacement occurs.

sec.p: The second measurement step aimed to check whether the vibration modes of the sample were ascribable to pure torsion. In that case, each surface portion of the beam, which is located in the region of its axis, is not subjected to any displacement contrary to those in close proximity to the opposite edges along the transverse direction. Apart from being different to zero, the latter would have equal and opposite values. The microphonic sensor was placed next to a beam edge where the tested surface region shows the maximum displacement. A linear and continuous motor moved the sensor towards the opposite edge, and the rms voltage signal from the measurement chain, applied to the y channel, was reported on a plotting system in the presence of a voltage, proportional to the sensor displacement, at the x one. The result relating to the resonant frequency of 5597.93 Hz is shown in Figure 8 whose right-hand vertical axis also reports the displacement A0 of the explored surface portion. Three sensor positions are traceable along the transverse direction, all corresponding to a zero value of the output signal; the central one is placed on the longitudinal axis. Two maxima of displacement are further highlighted with nearly equal amplitudes (0.38÷0.40μm) and positions corresponding to sensor placements on the edge surface portions of the beam. The two maxima are opposed in sign when they are displayed in time by an oscilloscope. The existence of a non-zero output voltage in the regions outside the beam must be ascribed to the extension of the microphone-sensing element that, not being punctiform, gradually overlaps the edge region during its approach.

caption.p: Output voltage from the measuring chain and corresponding displacement amplitude of the explored surface portion with the microphonic sensor moved along direction y (figure insert) from one edge to another. A, B and C are the positions on the beam surface corresponding to null and maximum displacements of one of its portions.

sec.p: The fact that the surface portions with zero displacement are placed on the longitudinal axis leads to the conclusion that the vibration of the prototype sample just corresponds to pure torsion. This result is repeatable for all the vibration modes whose frequencies are reported in Table 1.

With regard to the third measurement step, the sensor was placed on a surface portion next to the lateral edge and translated along the longitudinal direction with manually controlled micrometrical displacements. Sensor positions were looked for relating to the zero and maximum values of the output voltage. Since the readings of the latter were not associated with a negative or positive sign, the concurrent visualization in the time of the corresponding voltage signals was carried out by an oscilloscope (Figure 6(a)), which enabled checking for two successive maxima. Figure 9 shows a ‘deformation profile’ as a locus of the points representative of the displacement from the equilibrium of the investigated surface portion, corresponding to the measured frequency of 5597.630 Hz of the mode n = 7. These displacements can be associated with rotation angles of the cross section, which, in the case of pure torsion, are achievable from equation (7). The values relating to the frequencies investigated are shown in Table 1 for the maxima of angular displacement.

caption.p: Standing torsion wave of the seventh vibration mode representing the displacement distribution of a surface portion at any position of the sensor along the beam longitudinal direction. The table shows the distance of the nodes and anti-nodes from the clamp.

sec.p: In terms of sensor distance from the beam clamp, the table in Figure 9 shows the results for the mode n = 7 where null (nodes) and maximum (anti-nodes) displacements of the surface portion occur and for which the output voltage is respectively zero and a maximum. The succession of zeroes and maxima enables the definition of the spatial periodicity λ of the standing waves established in the laminar beam. It is possible to find its value by considering the zero positions that in this case are better defined than the maxima ones. Furthermore, among all the nodes, the most distant from the beam clamp were selected because their placements were less influenced by its presence. Using the d4 and d6 positions (Figure 9), the λ value was determined from the relationship

From the knowledge of λ and frequency f (5597.630 Hz), a propagation velocity v = λf = 363 m/s resulted for the wave perturbation in the vibrating beam. The deformation profiles built from the vibration modes for all the frequencies in Table 1 revealed the same amount of velocity with an accuracy estimated to be better than 5%.

Using the experimental set-up in Figure 7(a), the current I in the piezoelectric thick-film layers was measured in order to obtain an admittance spectrum of the prototype sample over the explored frequency range. The results are shown in Figure 10 where the peak positions corresponding to the vibration modes are highlighted, in addition to a non-monotonic dependence of their amplitudes on the relating frequencies. The latter are just those measured with the microphonic method, but with the present measurement procedure, more accurate values were obtained with a resolution better than 5 mHz and consequently good morphological definition of the peaks.

caption.p: Admittance peaks of the prototype sample corresponding to the first vibration modes.

sec.p: Figure 11 shows examples of such morphology with reference to the modes n = 3 and n = 7, where the former peak amplitude is lower than the latter, and in addition, a difference in their forms is evident. The frequency band within which the resonance phenomenon takes place is wider in the first case in comparison with the second one. Their respective widths, evaluated at half the amplitude of the peaks, enables the two forms to be quantitatively distinguished through the quality factor Q. For an elastic and continuous structure in forced vibration, this factor is expressed as

caption.p: Peak morphology for vibration modes n = 3 and n = 7.

sec.p: where E is the total mechanical energy at the resonant frequency f0, to which corresponds a maximum of amplitude of admittance; ΔE is its dissipated portion in a period, f1 and f2 are the frequencies at both ends of above-mentioned band, respectively.

In order to accurately determine Δf, the peak amplitude was obtained by subtracting from the admittance value in f0, the background level measured for a frequency out of the resonance band. Concerning f1 and f2, their value was found by increasing and decreasing the excitation frequency, until an admittance value equal to half the peak amplitude was achieved. The Q values are shown in the table in Figure 10 for each represented peak and repeated in Figure 11 for modes n = 3 and n = 7.

From the comparison of the results shown in Table 1 and Figure 10, it clearly appears that the microphonic and admittance methods provide measured values of the mode frequencies, characterized by a different number of significant digits, which is smaller for the first one. The operational procedure of finding the frequency values was the same for both of them, namely, that based on the change in excitation frequency around a resonance condition, in order to detect a maximum of the voltage signal from the measurement chain. Using the microphonic method, this signal originates from the pressure change in the air gap between the vibrating beam and sensor, in addition to the working modalities of its sensing element. This involves a resolution on the frequency measurements, which is limited by both the interposed fluid characteristics and the microphone sensitivity. Since the minimum change in output voltage that was detectable corresponded to a frequency of 0.1 Hz, such a value also sets the resolution. Vice versa, with the admittance method, the resolution is better than 5 × 10−3 Hz. Although in this case the definition of the resonance frequency is more accurate, it must be observed that it does not enable the detection of the positions of the nodes and anti-nodes differently from the microphonic measurements.

sec.title: Discussion of results and remarks
sec.p: The two methods of investigation provided experimental results whose analysis brings out vibration characteristics that are very close to those of pure torsion. The mode frequencies resulting from equation (3) and those measured by the admittance survey are reported in the table in Figure 10. From their comparison, a divergence of the values, increasing with the resonance frequency, appears, and even though it is not excessive (better than 7%), it is worth explaining its possible origins. The frequencies fn were calculated by giving the density ρ, elastic parameter Ct and geometrical dimensions the typical values of the beam. The density was measured as a mass-to-volume ratio, whereas the parameter Ct resulted from equation (2), where the beam shear modulus G appears, the value of which was calculated from the results of the microphonic sensor during a longitudinal translation. It was therefore possible to determine the wavelength λ of each mode, so that a velocity v of 363 m/s resulted with a variability within ±5% for all the examined resonance frequencies. A G value equal to 128 ± 10 GPa was obtained, which is not too far from that of alumina (130 GPa, Al2O3 96%). By neglecting the instrumental errors, estimated to be less than 0.5%, the divergence among the expected and measured mode frequencies is mainly due, with any chance, to the density value that was considered to be the same in the whole beam volume. This is not however the case of a real sample where, in defined portions of its surfaces, the layers of different materials are present in non-negligible thicknesses. Their mass, which brings about a non-uniform density distribution along the beam, together with their elastic characteristics, affects the dynamics of the vibrations, and this induces resonance frequencies that are different from the calculated ones. The shifting among the measured and calculated values appears to be emphasized at the higher frequencies because in the beam regions below the layers, more maxima of oscillation are present, and this leads to an increased influence on the vibration. In any case, the discrepancies of the values are not higher than 8%. It is reasonable to expect a further decrease if, in the ρ and G values, the contributions of elastic and inertial effects of layers are also considered. Since equation (3) is applicable in the case of pure torsion, it can be concluded that the vibration modes of the prototype sample just correspond to those relevant to that case.

In the admittance spectrum of Figure 10, the non-monotonic distribution of the peak amplitudes assigns the highest value to the mode n = 5, to which also the highest quality factor Q and then the lowest energy dissipation corresponds (Figure 11). From Table 1, this mode is also characterized by the maximum value reached from the torsion angle. All of this leads to the conclusion that at the excitation frequency of that mode, the maximum transfer of mechanical energy occurs from the piezoelectric-generating layer to the beam, and the condition of greatest efficiency is realized for the torsional vibration. In this situation, the spatial periodicity λ of the vibration is equal to 4p where p is the length of the beam portion taken from the ferroelectric layer, so a well-defined value of the ratio between it and the beam length exists, expressed as Lp=n with n an odd integer. The order n of the most efficient mode decreases for increasing p values, and if, for example, the layer covers all of the beam surface, the peak of maximum amplitude occurs at n = 1. By generalizing these observations, it can be stated that the excitation frequency for the most efficient energy transfer is determined by the dimension of the piezoelectric layer compared with the beam length. The mechanical energy lost in every cycle just arises in the volume of it where the ferroelectric grains make a consolidated structure, characterized by the presence of cavities and pores. Phenomena of internal friction activated in it by the electric field–induced strain remove a portion of the generated energy as heat. In order to evaluate the influence of layer extension on those phenomena, the dependence of the Q parameter on the layer dimension was investigated with the sample excited in vibration at the frequency of its seventh mode. By a simple ploy, the total length of the beam was changed so as to obtain different values of the ratio L/p with the same frequency and wavelength of the mode, so that Q is independent of λ.

This was obtained using a mechanical clamp placed in the beam positions where, for that mode, the nodes of oscillation occur. Even if the seventh mode selected is not the most efficient, its number of nodes, greater than that of the fifth one, makes a quantity of clamping seats, providing measurements sufficient for studying the aforesaid dependence, possible. In this case, the layer extension p does not change, unlike the length L, which, on the contrary, takes on values depending on the clamp position. The latter, due to its blocking action, reflects the torsion perturbation and makes the beam portion beyond it ineffective for the vibration. For the experimented positions, the Q values were obtained from the measurement results, while those of the dissipated fractional energy ΔE/E were given by equation (8). In Figure 12, they are shown depending on the ratio p/Ln where Ln is the distance from the constrained beam end of the interested node. From it, an increasing quality factor is noted for decreasing values of the aforesaid ratio, that is, for growing extensions of the beam portion involved in the vibration, a decrease in the lost fractional energy appears. This behaviour is equivalent to that of a beam of constant length, where the extension of the supported ferroelectric layer is changed. From an applicative point of view, what has been described here gains meaningful interest where the realization of vibrating beams in torsion, with maximum efficiency and high Q values, is required.

sec.p: Several prototype samples of the same type were realized with a reproducibility better than 3%, which gave measured values of the mode frequencies characterized by a repeatability that was changeable within a range of ±10 mHz. In addition, prolonged observations over the time of the vibrations showed a high stability of the resonance frequencies.

sec.title: Application prospects for sensors
sec.p: The results of this study were evaluated in the perspective of exploiting laminar beams, vibrating in torsion, as sensing elements for sensors of physical quantities. For the authors, this aspect is always present when starting experimental research aimed at studying and characterizing a physical phenomenon in materials and structures. In this case, there are many external stimuli that in various ways can influence the torsion dynamics of a laminar beam. By way of an example, proof is given here and commented on, which by taking advantage of the experimental set-up in Figure 7(a), concerns a prototype sample oriented vertically and implemented as shown in Figure 13(a).

caption.p: Use of a sample prototype as a force sensor: (a) application scheme of a load; (b) deformation profile relating to the mechanical clamp positioning in a node of vibration; (c) response of the sensor in terms of resonant frequency change induced by force.

sec.p: It was provided with a mechanical clamp that, in order to allow the application of the forces along its axis, supported hanging weights of calibrated mass. Its inertial moment around the axial direction was much larger than the beam one, so to act as a constraint that limits the angular rotation of the cross section at its application point. With the aim of using the results obtained from the admittance method, the application of the clamp must not change their values, so its positioning took place in the seats of the beam where, for the selected mode, a node was present. Figure 13(b) shows both the deformation profile of the vibrating beam and the clamp position. Among the investigated modes with the higher peak amplitudes, n = 5 and n = 7, the latter was selected because more evident effects, induced by the applied forces, were expected. The clamp and supported loads, by introducing an axial component of stress, modify the mode frequency and keep the condition of pure torsion unchanged. In the measurement procedure, the beam was put in vibration at the frequency of the seventh mode, and an increasing load, consisting of 10 masses of 50 g each, was applied to the clamp in succession. Following the addition of every mass, the vibration frequency changed because of the axial stress induced by its weight. The resonance condition was then re-established by changing the excitation frequency by block {3} in Figure 7(a) until the output voltage from block {5} in the same figure was maximized. The results are shown in Figure 13(c), in terms of the change in resonant frequency, which depends on the force generated by every applied mass. Over the changeability range of the latter, it increases with the force undergoing a change Δf = 4.6 Hz with regard to the resonance condition characterized by the mode frequency f7 = 5592.355 Hz without loads applied to the clamp. This frequency had a difference of 10 Hz from the one noted (5597.335 Hz) during the characterization phase where the clamp was absent. With a linearity error of ±3% over the explored range, the dependence form of Δf on the axial force F can be shown by the function Δf=SL·F where SL is the curve slope of Figure 13(c). From the functional point of view, that relationship represents the transfer characteristic of a sensor that converts a force into a frequency change with a sensitivity factor SL = 0.996 Hz/N. The measurement of resonant frequency was enabled by the experimental set-up with a resolution of 5 mHz, while the smallest change in force able to provoke a detectable effect on that frequency can be calculated from the sensitivity. Its value was 5.2 mN, and from it, the equivalent resolution in mass of 0.53 mg was obtained. Due to the dependence on the frequency measurement of the resolution in force, the latter is dependent both on the used experimental set-up and the morphological definition of the permittivity peak at the resonance. A beam vibrating in a mode characterized by a high-quality factor will have, for the same measurement apparatus, a resolution in force greater than what it would have corresponding to a vibration mode with a lower Q. This can become a criterion for addressing the selection of the optimal vibrating condition. The repetition of the entire measurement cycle indicated, for a determined force value in the range, a repeatability of the result that was better than ±5%. The main reason for this deviation of values is ascribable to a possible non-alignment of load due to the application method of single masses.

These results highlight a prerogative of the torsional vibration of laminar beams that motivates its experimentation as a working principle applicable to new sensors of various physical quantities for which interesting performance characteristics are expected. Research activities of authors in this framework are in progress at the moment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The knowledge of the stress state involved in a condition of pure torsion of laminar elements inspired research into the feasibility of the same condition by acting directly from their surface rather than through an external torque with an axial direction. The initiation of the related investigations was supported by the availability of flexible technology, allowing the easy realization of material layers on the surface of the elements, and the possibility of generating piezoelectric deformations with predetermined characteristics inside these layers. The goal was to evaluate the applicative potential of planar beams in the condition of torsional vibration as primary sensors of physical quantities. From the survey of the physical phenomena of interest, by way of devising suitable elastic structures, the realization of prototype samples was obtained, which can be laid in torsion through surface stresses, totally in plane, generated by piezoelectric thick-film layers. The in-depth analysis of the vibration modes allowed their association with the oscillations of pure torsion, and this made existing analytical relationships usable, which describe such kinds of dynamic behaviour in the case of laminar beams with constant rectangular cross sections. From them, operative conditions can be defined for the activation of specific vibration modes. All the experimental results were obtained by measuring the characteristic parameters of the vibration states, using the appropriately equipped experimental set-ups described earlier.

Their evaluation from an applicative viewpoint produced an investigative expansion of the effects induced on the forced vibration conditions, by the action of external physical quantities. In this framework, the interaction with axial loads and moments in addition to the rheology of fluids were probed. For each case, every feature of that interaction was considered together with the procedures of making the latter operatively and quantitatively describable. The results led to the writing of defined and univocal relationships between the external action and response of the vibrating beams by conferring on them the role of transfer functions for possible sensors of force, moment, magnetic field and viscosity. An example has been described regarding the application as a sensing element of a vibrating sample working on the frequency change in its vibration mode, produced by external axial forces.

From this kind of study, performances have emerged whose characteristics, besides suggesting their exploitation as sensing elements of beams vibrating in pure torsion, also highlighted ample opportunities for the development of new kinds of sensors. With this perspective, a prototype device was designed and realized that is able to measure both the density and viscosity of fluids based on a sensing element that, being conveniently equipped, vibrates in torsion partially immersed in a liquid. The interesting performance characteristics and the sensor description will be reported in an article that is soon to be submitted for publication. Another device, now in its experimental phase, has been devised and realized based on the integral coupling of a vibrating beam with a thin ferromagnetic sheet aimed at the measurement and survey of magnetic fields.

In conclusion, from what has been described here, it emerges that knowledge of the physical phenomena and the availability of a ferroelectric paste and related process technology enable a laminar beam to be transformed into a self-generating device able to place itself in dynamic conditions of pure torsion. This represents an opportunity worthy of consideration as the adoption of such a structure, besides conferring simplicity to the design and realization of a sensing element, may provide new applicative areas for torsional sensors.
